Cf ²Î¿´ heads(head1 5).  7 (idm Ï°Óï) have, etc one's tail betweenone's `legs (infml ¿Ú) be humiliated, dejected or defeated ¼ĞÖøÎ²°Í; ´¹Í·É¥Æø; Ôâµ½Ê§°Ü. heads I win, tails you lose => head1. heads or tails? => head1. make head or tail of sth => head1. on sb's `tail following sb closely ½ô¸úÄ³ÈË. a sting in the tail => sting1. the tail wagging the `dog situation in which a minor part of sth is controlling or determining the course of the whole Î²°ÍÒ¡¹·£¨´ÎÒª²¿·ÖÖ§Åä»ò¾ö¶¨È«¾Ö£©. turn `tail run away from a fight, etc £¨´Ó³åÍ»µÈ³¡ºÏÖĞ£©ÌÓ×ß, ÌÓÅÜ: As soon as they saw us coming they turned tail and ran. take off 
(a) (of an aeroplane, a helicopter, etc) leave the ground and begin to fly £¨Ö¸·É»úµÈ£©Æğ·É: The plane took off despite the fog. ¾¡¹ÜÓĞÎí, ·É»úÈÔÕÕ³£Æğ·É. (b) (infml ¿Ú) leave hurriedly or suddenly ´ÒÃ¦ÀëÈ¥; Í»È»ÀëÈ¥: He took off for the station at a run. Ëû´ÒÃ¦Ïò³µÕ¾ÅÜÈ¥. * When he saw the police coming he took off in the opposite direction. take-home pay 
amount of one's wages or salary remaining after taxes, etc have been deducted ÊµµÃ¹¤×Ê£¨¿Û³ıË°µÈáá¾»Ê£Õß£©.
take-off

take
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Both last and take are concerned with duration. *lastºÍtake¶¼Éæ¼°Ê±¼äµÄÑÓĞø.  1 Take indicates that a certain amount of time is needed in order to complete a task, journey, etc. *takeÖ¸×öÒ»¼şÊÂ¡¢ ×ßÒ»¶ÎÂ·µÈËùĞèµÄÊ±¼ä. Take must be used with an expression of time *take±ØĞëÓë±íÊ¾Ê±¼äµÄ´ÊÓïÁ¬ÓÃ: How long will the job take? ×öÕâÏî¹¤×÷ĞèÒª¶à³¤Ê±¼ä? * It takes a long time to get there. ÒªÓÃºÜ³¤Ê±¼ä²ÅÄÜµ½´ïÄÇÀï. * It took (me) four hours to write the essay. £¨ÎÒ£©Ğ´ÄÇÆªÎÄÕÂÓÃÁËËÄĞ¡Ê±. *  I'll clear up  you take too long. ÎÒÀ´ÇåÀí°É--ÄãÓÃµÄÊ±¼äÌ«³¤.2 Last indicates that an event will continue for a period of time or that there is enough of something for the required purpose. *lastÖ¸Ò»¼şÊÂËù³ÖĞøµÄÊ±¼ä»òÎª´ïµ½Ä³Ä¿µÄÓĞ³ä×ãµÄÌõ¼ş. Äã¿´ÄÇÓÍÆáÄÜÄÍ¾ÃÂğ?  3 Notice the difference between Çë×¢ÒâÏÂÃæÁ½¾ä»°µÄÇø±ğ: It takes (me) ten minutes to smoke a cigarette and A cigarette lasts (me) ten minutes. £à£¨ÎÒ£©ÎüÒ»Ö¦ÑÌÓÃÊ®·ÖÖÓ£§¼°£àÒ»Ö¦ÑÌ£¨ÎÒ£©¿ÉÎüÊ®·ÖÖÓ£§.  4 A journey can be seen as either a task or an event ×ßÒ»¶ÎÂ·³Ì¼È¿ÉÒÔ¿´×÷ÊÇÒ»Ïî¹¤×÷Ò²¿ÉÒÔ¿´×÷ÊÇÒ»¼şÊÂ: The journey takes/lasts two hours. ×ßÕâ¶ÎÂ·ÓÃÁ½Ğ¡Ê±.

talk
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 Talk as an uncountablenoun is a general word indicating the activity of speaking*talk×÷²»¿ÉÊıÃû´ÊÊ±, ÊÇ·ºÖ¸Ëµ»°ÕâÒ»»î¶¯µÄ´Ê: In politics there is too much talk and not enough action. talk
/ tR:k; tRk/ v  1 [I, Ipr] ~ (to/with sb) (about/of sth/sb) say things; speak to give information, discuss sth, etc Ëµ»°; Ì¸»°: We talked (ie to each other) for almost an hour. talk round sth

tenant

n [U].

thaw
/ WR:; WR/  v  1 (a) [I, Ip, Tn, Tn.p] ~ (sth) (out) (cause sth to) pass into an unfrozen or a liquid state after being frozen £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©½â¶³, ÈÚ»¯, ÈÚ½â: All the snow has thawed. ÌìÅ¯µÃ»¯¶³ÁË. =>?sage at water1 ÓÃ·¨¼ûwater1.  2 [I, Ip] ~ (out) (of people, their behaviour, etc) become less cool or formal in manner £¨Ö¸ÈË¡¢ Ì¬¶È¡¢ ĞĞÎªµÈ£©±äµÃÎÂºÍ¡¢ ²»Éõ¾ĞÀñ: After a few drinks the party atmosphere began to thaw (out). ºÈ¹ı¼¸±­¾ÆÖ®áá, ¾Û»áµÄÆø·Õ±äµÃÇáËÉ×ÔÈ»ÁË.
thaw

the(o)-
comb form ¹¹´Ê³É·Ö of God or a god ÉÏµÛµÄ; ÉñµÄ: theology * theocratic.
will-o-the-wisp

thin 
v (-nn-)  1 [I, Ip, Tn, Tn.p] ~ (sth) (out) (cause sth to) become less dense or fewer in number £¨Ê¹Ä³ÊÂÎï£©±äµÃÏ¡»òÉÙ: wait until the fog thins (out) µÈµ½Îí±ä±¡Ğ© * The traffic was thinning out. Ëû×Ô´Ó½ÚÖÆÒûÊ³ÒÔÀ´ÒÑ¾­ÊİÁË²»ÉÙ. thin sth down make sth thinner Ê¹Ä³Îï±ä±¡¡¢ Ï¸¡¢ Ï¡µÈ: thin down paint with white spirit ÓÃÊ¯ÓÍÈÜ¼ÁÏ¡ÊÍÓÍÆá.

thin
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Compare thin, skinny,underweight, slim, etc. ÊÔ±È½Ïthin¡¢ skinny¡¢underweight¡¢ slimµÈ´ÊµÄÓÃ·¨. When describing people whose weight is below normal, thin is the most general word. Ö¸ÈËµÄÌåÖØµÍì¶±ê×¼Ê±, thinÊÇ×î³£ÓÃµÄ´Ê. It may be negative, suggesting weakness or lack of health ¸Ã´Ê¿Éº¬±áÒå, Ö¸ĞéÈõ»ò²»½¡¿µ: She's gone terribly thin since her operation. Ëı¶¯¹ıÊÖÊõÒÔááÊİµÃºÜÀ÷º¦. Bony is often applied to parts of the body such as hands or face. *bonyÒ»´Ê³£ÓÃÀ´ĞŞÊÎÈËÌåµÄÄ³²¿·Ö, ÈçÊÖ»òÁ³. Skinny and scrawny are negative and can suggest lack of strength *skinnyºÍscrawny¶¼ÊÇ±áÒå´Ê, ±íÊ¾ÎŞÁ¦: He looks much too skinny/scrawny to be a weight-lifter. ËûÊİ¹Çá×á¾µÄ, µ±²»ÁË¾ÙÖØÔË¶¯Ô±. Underweight is the most neutral *underweight×îÎŞ°ı±áº¬Òå: The doctor says I'm underweight. Ò½ÉúËµÎÒµÄÌåÖØµÍì¶±ê×¼. Emaciated indicates a serious condition resulting from starvation. *emaciatedÖ¸Òò¼¢¶öÔì³ÉµÄÑÏÖØ×´¿ö. It is often thought desirable to be slim or slender, slim being used especially of those who have reduced their weight by diet or exercise *slim»òslender³£ÎªĞÄÏò ÍùÖ®µÄ, slimÒ»´ÊÓÈÓÃì¶ÃèÊö¾­½ÚÊ³»ò¶ÍÁ¶À´¼õÇáÌåÖØµÄÈË: I wish I was as slim as you. µ«Ô¸ÎÒÄÜÏñÄãÒ»ÑùÃçÌõ. *  You have a beautifully slender figure. think

ÄãÒªÊÇÏë×¬Ç®, ÄÔ×ÓÀï¾ÍµÃÏëÖøÇ®.  8 (idm Ï°Óï) I `thought as much that is what I expected or suspected ÎÒ¾ÍÊÇÕâ÷áÏëµÄ; ¹ûÈ»²»³öÎÒËùÁÏ. see/think fit => fit1. ,think a`gain reconsider the situation and change one's idea or intention ÖØĞÂ¿¼ÂÇÇé¿ö²¢¸Ä±äÏë·¨»òÒâÍ¼: If you think I'm going to lend you my car you can think again!ÄãÒªÊÇÒÔÎªÎÒÄÜ°ÑÆû³µ½è¸øÄã, Äã»¹ÊÇÁí´òÖ÷Òâ°É! think a`loud express one's thoughts as they occur ±ßÏë±ßËµ³öÉùÀ´; ×ÔÑÔ×ÔÓï. think better of (doing) sth decide against (doing) sth after thinking further about it £¨ÉîË¼áá£©¾ö¶¨²»²ÉÄÉÄ³ÊÂÎï»ò²»×öÄ³ÊÂ. think (all) the better of sb have a higher opinion of sb ¶ÔÄ³ÈËÓĞ¸ü¸ßµÄÆÀ¼Û. think nothing `of it (used as a polite response to apologies, thanks, etc ÓÃ×÷»ØÓ¦µÀÇ¸¡¢ ¸ĞĞ»µÈµÄ¿ÍÆø»°). think nothing of sth/doing sth consider(doing) sth to be normal and not particularly unusualÈÏÎª£¨×ö£©Ä³ÊÂºÜÆ½³£¡¢ ²»ÌØÊâ: She thinks nothing of walking thirty miles a day. think ahead (to sth)

(d) have the idea of sth ¶ÔÄ³ÊÂÎïÓĞ¼û½â (often used with could, would, should, and not or never ³£Óëcould¡¢ would¡¢ should¼°not¡¢ neverÁ¬ÓÃ): I couldn't think of letting you take the blame. throughout
/ Wru:5aUt; Wru`aJt/ adv  1 in every part ¸÷´¦; ¸÷·½Ãæ: The house was painted green throughout. ÄÇ·¿×ÓÕû¸öÍ¿³ÉÂÌÉ«µÄÁË. * Certain names in the book were underlined throughout. ÊéÖĞÔÚÄ³Ğ©Ãû×ÖÏÂÃæ¶¼»®ÁËÏß.  2 during the whole duration of sth ÔÚÄ³ÊÂµÄÕû¸öÆÚ¼ä: I watched the film and cried throughout. ÎÒ¿´ÄÇ¸öµçÓ°Ê±´ÓÍ·¿Şµ½Î².
throughout 
prep  1 in or into every part of (sth)ÔÚ»òÖÁ£¨Ä³Îï£©µÄ¸÷²¿·Ö: News spread throughout the country. ÕâÏûÏ¢´«±éÁËÈ«¹ú. * References to pain occur throughout the poem. throw

throw oneself at sth/sb 
(a) rush violently at sth/sb ³åÏòÄ³Îï[Ä³ÈË]. (b) (infml ¿Ú) (of a woman) make over-eager advances to (a man) £¨Ö¸Å®×Ó£©ÈÈÇĞÇ×½ü£¨ÄĞ×Ó£©: Everyone can see she's just throwing herself at him. Ë­¶¼¿´µÃ³öÀ´Ëı¸úËûÌ×½üºõ.
throw sth away

adv  1 tightly ½ô; ½ô½ôµØ; ÀÎÀÎµØ (not used beforea past participle: packed tight but tightly packed ¹ıÈ¥·Ö´ÊÖ®Ç°²»ÓÃtight¶øÓÃtightly: packed tight¼°tightly packed): Hold tight! ×¥½ôÁË!  2 (idm Ï°Óï) sit tight => sit. sleep tight => sleep2.

to
/ before consonants tE; tE, before vowels tU; tJ or tu:; tE; strong form tu:; tu ¸¨ÒôÇ°¶Á×÷tE, ÔªÒôÇ°¶Á×÷tU»òtu:; Ç¿¶ÁÊ½Îªtu:</PRON>/ (Used immediately before the simple (root) form of a v to form the infinitive. ÏÂÃæ½öÊÇ¶¯´Ê²»¶¨Ê½µÄ¼¸ÖÖÓÃ·¨; ÆäËûÓÃ·¨¼û¸÷Ãû´Ê¡¢ ĞÎÈİ´ÊºÍ¶¯´ÊµÄ´ÊÌõ. )  1 (used as the object of many vs, esp those labelled Tt, Tnt, Cn.t, Dpr.t, Dn.t ÓÃ×÷Ğí¶à¶¯´ÊµÄ±öÓï, ÓÈÆäÊÇ±êÓĞTt¡¢ Tnt¡¢ Cn.t¡¢ Dpr.t¡¢ Dn.tµÄ¶¯´Ê): He wants to go. ËûÏëÈ¥. * We had hoped to finish by four o'clock. ÎÒÃÇÔ­Ï£ÍûËÄµãÖÓÇ°ÄÜÍê³É. * She asked me to go. ËıÒªÇóÎÒÈ¥. * She persuaded him to tell the truth. toilet
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In British English the toilet in private houses is called the lavatory, toilet, WC (dated), or loo (informal). ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, Ë½ÈË×¡Õ¬ÖĞµÄ²ŞËù³ÆÎªthe lavatory¡¢ toilet¡¢ WC£¨ÒÑ³Â¾É£©»òloo£¨ÓÃì¶¿ÚÓï£©. In public places it is called the Gents/the Ladies or public conveniences. ¹«¹²³¡ËùµÄ²ŞËù³ÆÎªthe Gents/the Ladies»òpublic conveniences. In US English it is called the lavatory, toilet or bathroom in private houses and the washroom or rest-room in public buildings. ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞË½ÈË×¡Õ¬ÖĞµÄ²ŞËù³ÆÎª the lavatory¡¢ toilet »ò bathroom, ÔÚ¹«¹²½¨ÖşÎïÖĞµÄ³ÆÎª the washroom »ò rest-room.

token 
adj [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï]  1 serving as a sign or pledge of sth ÏóáçĞÔµÄ; ×÷Îª¶ÔÄ³ÊÂµÄ±£Ö¤µÄ: a token payment, ie payment of a small part of what is owed, as an acknowledgement of the debt ÏóáçĞÔµÄ³¥¸¶£¨³¥¸¶Ğ¡²¿·ÖÇ·¿î, ×÷Îª³ĞÈÏ¸ÃÕ®ÎñµÄÏóáç£© * a token strike, ie a short strike serving as a warning that a longer one may follow ÏóáçĞÔ°Õ¹¤£¨¶ÌÆÚ°Õ¹¤, ÒÔ¾¯¸æ¶Ô·½¿ÉÄÜ·¢¶¯³¤ÆÚ°Õ¹¤£©.  2 done, existing, etc on a small scale as a gesture of sth that is not seriously or sincerely meant; superficial or perfunctory ×°Ñù×ÓµÄ; ·óÑÜµÄ; ±íÃæµÄ: Our troops encountered only token resistance. ÎÒÃÇµÄ²¿¶Ó½öÊÜµ½±íÃæÉÏµÄµÖ¿¹. * a token attempt, effort, offer, etc ×°Ñù×ÓµÄ³¢ÊÔ¡¢ Å¬Á¦¡¢ ºÃÒâµÈ * the token woman on the committee, ie included to avoid charges of sexual discrimination Î¯Ô±»áÖĞ×ö×°µãµÄÅ®ĞÔ£¨ÒÔÃâÔâĞÔ±ğÆçÊÓµÄÖ¸Ôğ£©.

tone

too
/ tu:; tu/ adv  1 (usu placed at the end; in speech, with stress on too and on the word it modifies Í¨³£ÖÃì¶¾äÄ©; Ëµ»°Ê±, too¼°ÆäĞŞÊÎµÄ´ÊÖØ¶Á) in addition; also Ò²; ÓÖ; »¹: `I've been to Paris `too, ie in addition to other people. trade

trail

trail 
v  1 [I, Ipr, Ip, Tn, Tn.pr, Tn.p] (cause sth to) be dragged behind £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©±»ÍÏÔÚááÃæ: Her long skirt was trailing along/on the floor. travel
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The person who drives a car, bus or train is the person in control of it. ¿ªÆû³µ¡¢ ¹«¹²Æû³µ»ò»ğ³µÒªÓÃdriveÕâ¸ö´Ê. Similarly we ride a bicycle or horse, sail a boat or a ship (whether it sails or has an engine), and fly a plane. Æï×ÔĞĞ³µ»òÆïÂíÓÃride, ¼İ´¬£¨»òÓÃ·«»òÓÃ·¢¶¯»ú£©ÓÃsail, ¿ª·É»úÓÃfly. *We steer a car, bicycle or ship when we turn it in a particular direction. ¸Ä±äÆû³µ¡¢ ×ÔĞĞ³µ»ò´¬µÄ·½ÏòÓÃsteer. *When travelling as a passenger we ride in a car, bus or train, sail in a ship, and fly in a plane. ×÷Îª³Ë¿Í, ×øÆû³µ¡¢ ¹«¹²Æû³µ»ò»ğ³µÓÃride in, ×ø´¬ÓÃsail in, ×ø·É»úÓÃfly in. When talking about means of transport we can use go by (car, boat/ship/sea, plane/air, bicycle, etc) Ì¸µ½½»Í¨¹¤¾ß, ÓÃgo by (car¡¢ boat/ship/sea¡¢ plane/air¡¢ bicycleµÈ): Are you going by sea or by air? Äã´òËã×ø´¬È¥»¹ÊÇ×ø·É»úÈ¥? * He always comes to work by bus. Ëû×ÜÊÇ×ø¹«¹²Æû³µÀ´ÉÏ°à.

/ traI; traI/ v (pt, pp tried)  1 [I, It] (In informal use, try to + infinitive is often replaced by try and + infinitive, esp in the imperative, and don't/didn't try to by don't/didn't try and. turn (sb) against sb

turn around 
= turn round.
turn away (from sb/sth) 
stop facing or looking at sb/sth ×ª¹ıÁ³²»Ãæ¶Ô»ò²»ÔÙ¿´ÖøÄ³ÈË[Ä³Îï]: She turned away in horror at the sight of so much blood. ËıÒ»¿´¼ûÕâ÷á¶àÑª¾ÍÁ¢¿ÌÏÅµÃ×ª¹ıÁ³È¥. turn sb away (from sth) refuse to allow sb to enter a place; refuse to give help or support to sb ²»×¼Ä³ÈË½øÈëÄ³´¦; ¾Ü¾ø°ïÖú»òÖ§³ÖÄ³ÈË: Hundreds of people had to be turned away from the stadium, eg because it was full. turn (sb/sth) back

ÌìÆø±äµÃºÜ»µ, ËûÃÇÖ»ºÃÔ­Â·¶ø¹éÁË. * (fig ±ÈÓ÷) The project must go ahead; there can be no turning back. Õâ¼Æ»­±ØĞë¼á³ÖÏÂÈ¥, ²»ÄÜ´òÍËÌÃ¹Ä. * Our car was turned back at the frontier. turn sb/sth down

take sb in 
(a) allow sb to stay in one's home, sometimes for payment ÔÊĞíÄ³ÈË¼ÄËŞ¼ÒÖĞ: She takes in lodgers. ËıÕĞÊÕ¼ÄËŞÕß. * He was homeless, so we tookhim in. ËûÎŞ¼Ò¿É¹é, ÎÒÃÇ¾ÍÊÕÁôÁËËû. (b) (often passive³£ÓÃì¶±»¶¯ÓïÌ¬) deceive, delude or fool sb ÆÛÆ­¡¢ ÃÉ±Î»òÓŞÅªÄ³ÈË: She took me in completely with her story. ËıÓÃ»Ñ»°°ÑÎÒÍêÈ«ÃÉ±ÎÁË. * You won't take me in that easily! Äã±ğÒÔÎªÎÒÄÇ÷áÈİÒ×ÉÏµ±! * Don't be taken in by his charming manner; he's completely ruthless. ²»Òª±»ËûÄÇ¸±ÌÖÈËÏ²»¶µÄÍâ±íËùÃÔ»ó, ÆäÊµËûÀä¿áÎŞÇé. take sth in (a) absorb sth into the body by breathing or swallowing it ½«Ä³ÎïÎüÈë»òÍÌÈë£¨ÌåÄÚ£©; ÉãÈ¡: Fish take in oxygen through their gills. (d) include or cover sth °üÀ¨; °üº¬; °üÂŞ: The United Kingdom takes in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. take off

take up 
continue ¼ÌĞø: This chapter takes up where the last one left off. ±¾ÕÂ½ÓĞøÉÏÒ»ÕÂÌ¸µ½µÄÄÚÈİ. take up sth fill or occupy (the specified space or time) ÌîÂú, Õ¼¾İ£¨Ä³¿Õ¼ä»òÊ±¼ä£©: This table takes up too much room. (j) mention sth in order that it may be discussed Ìá³öÄ³ÊÂ£¨ÒÔÆÚÉÌÌÖ£©: I'd like to take up the point you raised earlier. ÎÒÏë°ÑÄãÔøÌá¹ıµÄÎÊÌâÌá³öÀ´ÌÖÂÛÒ»ÏÂ. take sb up (on sth) question or challenge sb (about sth); argue with sb (about sth) Ñ¯ÎÊ»òÖÊÎÊÄ³ÈË£¨Ä³ÊÂ£©; ÓëÄ³ÈËÕùÂÛ£¨Ä³ÊÂ£©: I must take you up on that point. ÎÒÒ»¶¨Òª¾ÍÄÇ¸öÎÊÌâºÍÄã±çÂÛ. * I'd like to take you up on what you said about unemployment. ¶Ôì¶ÄãÌ¸¹ıµÄÊ§ÒµÇé¿ö, ÎÒÏëÏòÄãÌá³öÎÊÌâ. take up with sb (infml ¿Ú) begin to be friendly with or spend a lot of time with sb (esp sb unpleasant or disreputable) ¿ªÊ¼ÓëÄ³ÈË£¨ÓÈÖ¸²»ºÃµÄÈË£©½»Íù: She's taken up with an unemployed actor. take
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Both last and take are concerned with duration. *lastºÍtake¶¼Éæ¼°Ê±¼äµÄÑÓĞø.  1 Take indicates that a certain amount of time is needed in order to complete a task, journey, etc. *takeÖ¸×öÒ»¼şÊÂ¡¢ ×ßÒ»¶ÎÂ·µÈËùĞèµÄÊ±¼ä. Take must be used with an expression of time *take±ØĞëÓë±íÊ¾Ê±¼äµÄ´ÊÓïÁ¬ÓÃ: How long will the job take? ×öÕâÏî¹¤×÷ĞèÒª¶à³¤Ê±¼ä? * It takes a long time to get there. ÒªÓÃºÜ³¤Ê±¼ä²ÅÄÜµ½´ïÄÇÀï. * It took (me) four hours to write the essay. £¨ÎÒ£©Ğ´ÄÇÆªÎÄÕÂÓÃÁËËÄĞ¡Ê±. *  I'll clear up  you take too long. ÎÒÀ´ÇåÀí°É--ÄãÓÃµÄÊ±¼äÌ«³¤.2 Last indicates that an event will continue for a period of time or that there is enough of something for the required purpose. *lastÖ¸Ò»¼şÊÂËù³ÖĞøµÄÊ±¼ä»òÎª´ïµ½Ä³Ä¿µÄÓĞ³ä×ãµÄÌõ¼ş. The time expression is not obligatory ²»Ò»¶¨ÒªÓĞ±íÊ¾Ê±¼äµÄ´ÊÓï: His illness has lasted a long time. ËûÒÑ²¡ÁËºÜ³¤Ê±¼ä. *  I hope this fine weather lasts. ÎÒÏ£ÍûÕâÑùµÄºÃÌìÆøÄÜ³ÖĞøÏÂÈ¥. *  Do you think that paint will last (out)? Äã¿´ÄÇÓÍÆáÄÜÄÍ¾ÃÂğ?  3 Notice the difference between Çë×¢ÒâÏÂÃæÁ½¾ä»°µÄÇø±ğ: It takes (me) ten minutes to smoke a cigarette and A cigarette lasts (me) ten minutes. £à£¨ÎÒ£©ÎüÒ»Ö¦ÑÌÓÃÊ®·ÖÖÓ£§¼°£àÒ»Ö¦ÑÌ£¨ÎÒ£©¿ÉÎüÊ®·ÖÖÓ£§.  4 A journey can be seen as either a task or an event ×ßÒ»¶ÎÂ·³Ì¼È¿ÉÒÔ¿´×÷ÊÇÒ»Ïî¹¤×÷Ò²¿ÉÒÔ¿´×÷ÊÇÒ»¼şÊÂ: The journey takes/lasts two hours. ×ßÕâ¶ÎÂ·ÓÃÁ½Ğ¡Ê±.

talk
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 Talk as an uncountablenoun is a general word indicating the activity of speaking*talk×÷²»¿ÉÊıÃû´ÊÊ±, ÊÇ·ºÖ¸Ëµ»°ÕâÒ»»î¶¯µÄ´Ê: In politics there is too much talk and not enough action. Talk can also be a countable noun referring to a (usually) short informal speech to a smallaudience, or, when used in the plural, to formal occasionsof serious talking, often between politicians *talk»¹¿É×÷¿ÉÊıÃû´Ê, £¨Í¨³££©Ö¸ÔÚÆÕÍ¨³¡ºÏ¶ÔÉÙÊıÈË·¢±íµÄ¼ò¶Ì½²»°; ¶ø×÷¸´ÊıÊ±Ôò³£Ö¸ÕşÖÎ¼ÒÖ®¼äÔÚ×¯ÖØµÄ³¡ºÏÖĞ½øĞĞµÄÑÏËàÌ¸»°: She gave the society an illustrated talk on her travels in India. ËıÔÚĞ­»áÖĞ½èÖúÍ¼Æ¬½²ÊöÆäÓ¡¶ÈÖ®ĞĞ. * The two sides in the war have agreed to hold peace talks. ½»Õ½Ë«·½Í¬Òâ¾ÙĞĞºÍÌ¸.  2 Discussion indicates (a) talk with a serious purpose. *discussionÖ¸ÓĞÖØÒªÄ¿µÄÖ®Ì¸»°. It is often a formal exchange of words in which speakers argue about and examine different aspects of a subject ÕâÒ»´Ê³£Ö¸·¢ÑÔÕß¾ÍÄ³ÎÊÌâµÄ¸÷¸ö·½Ãæ½»»»Òâ¼û¼°½øĞĞ±çÂÛ: The problem was solved only after several lengthy discussions. ÎÒ¼¸ÄêÃ»¼ûËûÁË, ÎÒÃÇÁÄ¹ıÈ¥µÄÊÂÁÄÁËºÜ³¤Ê±¼ä.  5 Gossip is derogatory and refers to talk about the private lives of other people, often of a critical kind. *gossipÊÇ±áÒå´Ê, Ö¸ÒéÂÛËûÈËµÄË½Éú»î, ³£ÓĞÌôÌŞĞÔÖÊ. talk
/ tR:k; tRk/ v  1 [I, Ipr] ~ (to/with sb) (about/of sth/sb) say things; speak to give information, discuss sth, etc Ëµ»°; Ì¸»°: We talked (ie to each other) for almost an hour. ÎÒµ¹Òª¿´¿´ËûÄÜËµ»áµÀ¹ıµÃÈ¥ÕâÒ»¹Ø. talking of sb/sth while on the subject of sb/sth Ëµµ½»òÌáµ½Ä³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]: Talking of Jim, have you heard that he's getting married? talk back (to sb) 
reply defiantly to a reprimand, etc »Ø×ì; ¶¥×ì.
talk sb down

than

thaw
/ WR:; WR/  v  1 (a) [I, Ip, Tn, Tn.p] ~ (sth) (out) (cause sth to) pass into an unfrozen or a liquid state after being frozen £¨Ê¹Ä³Îï£©½â¶³, ÈÚ»¯, ÈÚ½â: All the snow has thawed. the
/ TE, TI; TE, TI; strong form Ç¿¶ÁÊ½ Ti:; Ti/ ¼û´ÊÌõÊ¹ÓÃÏêÏ¸ËµÃ÷ 6.2. =>Usage at a2 ÓÃ·¨¼ûa2. def art (used to make the following n refer to a specific person, thing, event or group ÓÃì¶Ãû´ÊÇ°, ±íÊ¾ÎªÌØÖ¸µÄÈË¡¢ Îï¡¢ ÊÂ»òÈºÌå)  1 (when it has already been mentioned or implied Ö¸ÒÑÌáµ½¹ıµÄ»òÒÑÖªËùÖ¸µÄÈË¡¢ Îï¡¢ ÊÂ»òÈºÌå): A boy and a girl were sitting on a bench. thick
/ WIk; WIk/ adj (-er, -est)  1 of relatively great distance or of a specified distance between opposite surfaces or sides ºñµÄ; ´ÖµÄ: a thick slice of bread ºñºñµÄÒ»Æ¬Ãæ°ü * a thick line Ò»Ìõ´ÖÏß * ice three inches thick ÈıÓ¢´çºñµÄ±ù * a thick coat, pullover, etc, ie made of thick material ºñ´óÒÂ¡¢ Ì×Í·Ã«ÒÂµÈ.  2 having a large number of units close together ³íÃÜµÄ; ÃÜ¼¯µÄ; Ã¯ÃÜµÄ: a thick forest ÃÜÁÖ * thick hair Å¨ÃÜµÄÍ··¢ * in the thickest part of the crowd ÈËÈºÖĞ×î³íÃÜÖ®´¦.  3 (of a liquid or paste) relatively stiff in consistency; not flowing easily £¨Ö¸ÒºÌå»òºı×´Îï£©Å¨µÄ, ğ¤³íµÄ: thick soup, paint, glue Å¨ÌÀ¡¢ ³íÓÍÆá¡¢ ğ¤½º.  4 (of a vapour or the atmosphere) not clear; dense £¨Ö¸Æû¡¢ ÑÌ¡¢ Îí»ò¿ÕÆø£©²»Çå³ºµÄ, »ì×ÇµÄ, Å¨µÄ: thick fog, mist, cloud Å¨Îí¡¢ ÖØÎí¡¢ ÃÜÔÆ * thick darkness »è°µ.  5 (a) (of the voice) unclear, eg because one has a cold; indistinct £¨Ö¸É¤Òô£©²»Çå³şµÄ£¨ÈçÒòÉË·çËùÖÂ£©. thin
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Compare thin, skinny,underweight, slim, etc. ÊÔ±È½Ïthin¡¢ skinny¡¢underweight¡¢ slimµÈ´ÊµÄÓÃ·¨. When describing people whose weight is below normal, thin is the most general word. Ö¸ÈËµÄÌåÖØµÍì¶±ê×¼Ê±, thinÊÇ×î³£ÓÃµÄ´Ê. It may be negative, suggesting weakness or lack of health ¸Ã´Ê¿Éº¬±áÒå, Ö¸ĞéÈõ»ò²»½¡¿µ: She's gone terribly thin since her operation. Ëı¶¯¹ıÊÖÊõÒÔááÊİµÃºÜÀ÷º¦. Bony is often applied to parts of the body such as hands or face. *bonyÒ»´Ê³£ÓÃÀ´ĞŞÊÎÈËÌåµÄÄ³²¿·Ö, ÈçÊÖ»òÁ³. Skinny and scrawny are negative and can suggest lack of strength *skinnyºÍscrawny¶¼ÊÇ±áÒå´Ê, ±íÊ¾ÎŞÁ¦: He looks much too skinny/scrawny to be a weight-lifter. ËûÊİ¹Çá×á¾µÄ, µ±²»ÁË¾ÙÖØÔË¶¯Ô±. Underweight is the most neutral *underweight×îÎŞ°ı±áº¬Òå: The doctor says I'm underweight. Ò½ÉúËµÎÒµÄÌåÖØµÍì¶±ê×¼. Emaciated indicates a serious condition resulting from starvation. *emaciatedÖ¸Òò¼¢¶öÔì³ÉµÄÑÏÖØ×´¿ö. It is often thought desirable to be slim or slender, slim being used especially of those who have reduced their weight by diet or exercise *slim»òslender³£ÎªĞÄÏò ÍùÖ®µÄ, slimÒ»´ÊÓÈÓÃì¶ÃèÊö¾­½ÚÊ³»ò¶ÍÁ¶À´¼õÇáÌåÖØµÄÈË: I wish I was as slim as you. µ«Ô¸ÎÒÄÜÏñÄãÒ»ÑùÃçÌõ. *  You have a beautifully slender figure. ÄãµÄÌåĞÎÊ®·ÖÃçÌõ.

throughout
/ Wru:5aUt; Wru`aJt/ adv  1 in every part ¸÷´¦; ¸÷·½Ãæ: The house was painted green throughout. ÄÇ·¿×ÓÕû¸öÍ¿³ÉÂÌÉ«µÄÁË. * Certain names in the book were underlined throughout. throughout

Õ¨µ¯Ñ¡ÔÚÈË×î¶àÊ±±¬Õ¨.  2 [Tn] (sport Ìå) make (a stroke) or strike (the ball) at a certain moment £¨ÔÚÄ³Ò»Ê±¿Ì£©·¢³ö£¨Ò»»÷£©»ò»÷£¨Çò£©: He timed that shot beautifully. ËûÕâÒ»»÷Ê±¼äÇ¡µ½ºÃ´¦.  3 [Tn, Tw] measure the time taken by (a runner, etc) or for (a race, process, etc) £¨ÎªÅÜÕß¡¢ ÈüÅÜ¡¢ Ä³¹ı³ÌµÈ£©¼ÆÊ±: This egg is hard  you didn't time it properly. to

to
/ before consonants tE; tE, before vowels tU; tJ or tu:; tE; strong form tu:; tu ¸¨ÒôÇ°¶Á×÷tE, ÔªÒôÇ°¶Á×÷tU»òtu:; Ç¿¶ÁÊ½Îªtu:</PRON>/ (Used immediately before the simple (root) form of a v to form the infinitive. toilet
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In British English the toilet in private houses is called the lavatory, toilet, WC (dated), or loo (informal). ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, Ë½ÈË×¡Õ¬ÖĞµÄ²ŞËù³ÆÎªthe lavatory¡¢ toilet¡¢ WC£¨ÒÑ³Â¾É£©»òloo£¨ÓÃì¶¿ÚÓï£©. In public places it is called the Gents/the Ladies or public conveniences. ¹«¹²³¡ËùµÄ²ŞËù³ÆÎªthe Gents/the Ladies»òpublic conveniences. In US English it is called the lavatory, toilet or bathroom in private houses and the washroom or rest-room in public buildings. ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞË½ÈË×¡Õ¬ÖĞµÄ²ŞËù³ÆÎª the lavatory¡¢ toilet »ò bathroom, ÔÚ¹«¹²½¨ÖşÎïÖĞµÄ³ÆÎª the washroom »ò rest-room.

/ tEUn; ton/ n  1 [C] sound, esp with reference to its pitch, quality, strength, etc ÉùÒô; Òôµ÷; ÒôÖÊ: the ringing tones of an orator's voice ÑİËµÕßºêÁÁµÄÉùÒô * the alarm bell's harsh tone ´Ì¶úµÄ¾¯ÖÓµÄÉùÒô.  2 [C] manner of expression in speaking ÓïÆø; ¿ÚÆø; Ç»µ÷: speak in an angry, impatient, entreating, etc tone ÒÔ·ßÅ­¡¢ ²»ÄÍ·³¡¢ ¿ÒÇóµÈµÄÓïÆøËµ»° * a tone of command, reproach, regret, etc ÃüÁî¡¢ Ôğ±¸¡¢ ±§Ç¸µÈµÄ¿ÚÆø * Don't speak to me in that tone (of voice), ie in that unpleasant, insolent, critical, etc way. ±ğÓÃÄÇÖÖÇ»µ÷¸úÎÒËµ»°.  3 [C, U] quality or character of sound produced by a musical instrument £¨ÀÖÆ÷µÄ£©ÒôÖÊ, ÒôÉ«: a violin with (an) excellent tone ÒôÉ«ÓÅÃÀµÄĞ¡ÌáÇÙ.  4 [sing] general spirit or character of sth Ä³ÊÂÎïµÄ¸ñµ÷»òÌØĞÔ: Overall, the tone of the book is satirical/the book is satirical in tone. ×ÜµÄËµÀ´, Õâ±¾ÊéÊÇ·í´ÌĞÔµÄ. * set the tone for/of the meeting with a conciliatory speech ÒÔ±íÊ¾ºÍ½âµÄ½²»°Îª»áÒé¶¨µ÷×Ó * lower/raise the tone of a conversation, an occasion, an organization, ie make it worse/better Ê¹Ì¸»°²»Í¶»ú[Í¶»ú]¡¢ ³åµ­[Ôö¼Ó]Ò»³¡ºÏµÄÆø·Õ¡¢ ¼õÈõ[ÔöÇ¿]Ò»×éÖ¯µÄÉùÊÆ.  5 [C] (music Òô) any one of the five larger intervals between one note and the next that (together with two semitones) make up an octave È«Òô.  6 [C] (a) tint or shade (of a colour); degree (of light) É«¶È; ¹â¶È: a carpet in tones of brown and orange ÓĞ×ØÉ«ºÍ³ÈÉ«½»Ö¯µÄÒ»¿éµØÌº. town centre

travel
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The person who drives a car, bus or train is the person in control of it. ¿ªÆû³µ¡¢ ¹«¹²Æû³µ»ò»ğ³µÒªÓÃdriveÕâ¸ö´Ê. Similarly we ride a bicycle or horse, sail a boat or a ship (whether it sails or has an engine), and fly a plane. Æï×ÔĞĞ³µ»òÆïÂíÓÃride, ¼İ´¬£¨»òÓÃ·«»òÓÃ·¢¶¯»ú£©ÓÃsail, ¿ª·É»úÓÃfly. *We steer a car, bicycle or ship when we turn it in a particular direction. ¸Ä±äÆû³µ¡¢ ×ÔĞĞ³µ»ò´¬µÄ·½ÏòÓÃsteer. *When travelling as a passenger we ride in a car, bus or train, sail in a ship, and fly in a plane. ×÷Îª³Ë¿Í, ×øÆû³µ¡¢ ¹«¹²Æû³µ»ò»ğ³µÓÃride in, ×ø´¬ÓÃsail in, ×ø·É»úÓÃfly in. When talking about means of transport we can use go by (car, boat/ship/sea, plane/air, bicycle, etc) Ì¸µ½½»Í¨¹¤¾ß, ÓÃgo by (car¡¢ boat/ship/sea¡¢ plane/air¡¢ bicycleµÈ): Are you going by sea or by air? Äã´òËã×ø´¬È¥»¹ÊÇ×ø·É»úÈ¥? * He always comes to work by bus. Ëû×ÜÊÇ×ø¹«¹²Æû³µÀ´ÉÏ°à.

treat
/ tri:t; trit/ v  1 [Tn, Tn.pr, Cn.n/a] ~ sb (as/like sth) act or behave in a certain way towards sb ¶Ô´ıÄ³ÈË: They treat their children very badly. turn

turn (sb) against sb

turn around 
= turn round.
